title: DUCKS: Old foe Jones bests Andersen, Anaheim
text:
BY ERIC STEPHENS / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 Updated: Oct. 11, 2015 9:53 a.m. SAN JOSE â" It didnât take long for Frederik Andersen to prove himself worthy of being the Ducksâ No. 1 goaltender for the first time to start a season.
But in the case of their opener Saturday night, San Joseâs Martin Jones did him one better in making a convincing case why he is the Sharksâ new main man in net.
Jones stopped 27 shots to win a goaltending duel with Andersen as Patrick Marleauâs two goals proved decisive in a 2-0 victory over the Ducks, who were the final NHL team to get its season going.
Andersen made 42 saves in a strong opening effort but the veteran Marleau broke through on his second-chance effort with 38.1 seconds left in the second and then slipped a wraparound try between Andersenâs pads with 4:50 remaining in the third.
The Ducks know all about Jones, facing him three prior times when he was the Kingsâ backup to Jonathan Quick. Jones got his first victory against them on Dec. 3, 2013 when he foiled all nine shootout tries in a 3-2 victory.
With Quick entrenched in Los Angeles for the foreseeable future, the Kings traded Jones to Boston and the Sharks promptly got him from the Bruins as the successor to Antti Niemi. Jones has started to win over the fans at SAP Center.
In the first period, Jones made a point-blank save on Jiri Sekac from the high slot after Rickard Rakell set up his winger with a perfect pass to the middle. In the second period, it was a high-grade rebound attempt by Perry that was denied and a backhand try by Sekac that was foiled.
The Sharks are trying to rebound from missing the playoffs last season. In addition to bringing in Jones, they made their biggest change in breaking ties with longtime coach Todd McLellan and hiring veteran Peter DeBoer.
DeBoer has the Sharks going early. San Jose started off with a dominating 5-1 win over the Kings on Wednesday night and it gradually took control of Saturdayâs game after a slow start.
And if Jones gives them the kind of goaltending that heâs shown so far, the Sharks could find themselves back in the postseason mix. Right now, the Ducks have to find a way to get the edge on their northern rival after losing four of five matchups last season.
âOf course, in the long run the divisional games will take on more meaning because youâll be able to see lights at the end of the tunnel and the point differentials here,â Ducks coach Bruce Boudreau said. âBut I think for us, itâs getting off on the right foot.
âI think weâve worked hard as a group in training camp. And weâre playing a team that we thought was very impressive against Los Angeles the other night. Itâs going to be a tough battle.â
Boudreau stuck to his plan of having offensive stars Perry and Ryan Getzlaf play on different lines. Perry was effective in the third forward grouping with Sekac and Rickard Rakell, while Getzlaf and linemates Carl Hagelin and Chris Stewart generated little.
The experiment that took place all throughout the preseason ended midway through the third when Boudreau put Getzlaf and Perry back together.
